fullText: King Charles III is a brilliant piece of theatrical speculation that imagines what might happen if the future king decided to flex his constitutional muscles.
dtliExcerpt: King Charles III is a brilliant piece of theatrical speculation that imagines what might happen if the future king decided to flex his constitutional muscles.
bwwExcerpt: As the use of blank verse suggests, Bartlett aims to dress up the skeeviness of this speculative royal-watching in Shakespearean grandeur, and he mostly succeeds. The iambic pentameter is supple and amusing ('But here's my husband, he's been on the phone') even if it depends a bit too much on auxiliary verbs to fill out the lines. The scene-closing couplets, the elaborately extended metaphors, the near quotations ('Say more. For nothing comes of nothing said') all support in language the Shakespeare-sized themes and characters he has tossed into the blender.
